column7: Police went on a rampage in Nairobi’s Kibera slum, raping, beating, looting and destroying property, causing thousands of residents to flee
column13: {"event_family": "violence", "subtype": "police use of force", "severity": {"fatalities": null, "injuries_est": null, "arrests_est": null, "property_damage": "med"}, "crowd_est": null, "election_cycle": 2002}

column7: In Kariobangi, vigilante gangs allied to ethnic groups and politicians killed residents; police made arrests but prosecutions did not follow.
column13: {"event_family": "violence", "subtype": "vigilante attack", "severity": {"fatalities": null, "injuries_est": null, "arrests_est": null, "property_damage": "med"}, "crowd_est": null, "election_cycle": 2002}

column7: The IMF suspended lending to Kenya due to corruption concerns in late 2000 and resumed lending in November 2003 under the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility.
column13: {"shock_type": "financial", "severity": "medium"}

column7: The IMF approved a loan of about $252.75 million under its Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility, allowing Kenya to draw $36.11 million immediately. Conditions included freezing civil-service wages and retrenching 45,000 workers.
column13: {"contributor": "IMF", "recipient": "Kenya", "immediate_draw": "36.11e6", "conditions": ["freeze wages", "retrenched 45,000 workers"]}

column7: Violent rallies and clashes leading up to the 21 November 2005 constitutional referendum resulted in several deaths; supporters of the “no” campaign celebrated after early results showed they were winning.
column8: Supporters of Yes vs No campaigns; police
column13: {"event_family": "riot", "subtype": "violent protest", "severity": {"fatalities": null, "injuries_est": null, "arrests_est": null, "property_damage": "low"}, "crowd_est": null, "election_cycle": 2007}

column7: Kenya’s 2000/2001 budget estimated total spending of Ksh 266.2 billion, with 94 % (Ksh 250.906 billion) for recurrent expenditures and only 6 % (Ksh 15.306 billion) for development. Debt service consumed about 41 % (Ksh 109.9 billion), while salaries, operations and maintenance accounted for 53 %.
column13: {"fiscal_year": "2000/01", "debt_service": "109.9e9", "development": "15.306e9"}

column6: Police break up peaceful constitutional reform protest
column7: Police fired tear gas and water cannons to disperse several hundred protesters who marched on parliament demanding a referendum on constitutional reform.
column9: constitutional reform, police use of force
column13: {"event_family": "crackdown", "subtype": "police dispersal of protest", "severity": {"fatalities": null, "injuries_est": null, "arrests_est": null, "property_damage": "low"}, "crowd_est": "hundreds", "election_cycle": null}

column6: Economic hardship and political unrest linkage
column7: The suspension of IMF lending and conditions of the resumed PRGF loan aggravated economic hardships that fuelled public dissatisfaction, contributing to protests during the 2005 constitutional referendum.
column13: {"source_type": "shock", "source_id": "shock_2003_imf_freeze", "target_type": "incident", "target_id": "incident_2005_referendum_rallies", "relation": "amplified", "mechanism_note": "Economic austerity and structural-adjustment conditions reduced livelihoods, heightening public grievances that manifested in protests during the referendum.", "confidence": 0.3, "evidence_refs": ["\u3010696902548373840\u2020L82-L120\u3011", "\u301046168072966761\u2020L156-L170\u3011"]}

column7: The share of informal employment in total non-agricultural employment in Kenya rose to about 70% in the early 2000s, reflecting the dominance of informal work and limited formal job creation.
column13: {"indicator_name": "share of non-agricultural employment in informal sector", "value": 70.1, "unit": "percent", "direction": "up", "population_group": "workers", "data_source_type": "report", "data_granularity": "multi-year"}

column7: Labour market statistics indicate that by 2021 the informal economy accounted for roughly 83% of total employment in Kenya, continuing an upward trend in informal labour.
column13: {"indicator_name": "informal employment ratio", "value": 83, "unit": "percent", "direction": "up", "population_group": "workers", "data_source_type": "survey", "data_granularity": "multi-year"}

column6: Informal sector share of new jobs (2017)
column7: Kenya’s Economic Survey 2018 reported that approximately 83.4% of the 897,800 new jobs created in 2017 were in the informal sector, underscoring the sector’s role in job creation.
column13: {"indicator_name": "share of new jobs created by informal sector", "value": 83.4, "unit": "percent", "direction": "unknown", "population_group": "newly employed", "data_source_type": "survey", "data_granularity": "annual"}

column7: A Business Daily report noted that local small and medium-sized enterprises — many of which operate informally — employed nearly 85% of the Kenyan workforce in 2019, though they faced low demand from consumers and large firms.
column13: {"indicator_name": "SME employment share", "value": 85, "unit": "percent", "direction": "unknown", "population_group": "workforce", "data_source_type": "report", "data_granularity": "annual"}

column6: Social protection coverage for informal workers (2022)
column7: A World Bank Kenya economic update observed that social protection programmes such as Haba Haba and Mbao help informal workers save for retirement, but social assistance spending is only about 0.3% of GDP and coverage remains low among informal workers.
column13: {"indicator_name": "social protection spending as share of GDP", "value": 0.3, "unit": "percent_of_GDP", "direction": "unknown", "population_group": "informal workers", "data_source_type": "report", "data_granularity": "annual"}

column6: COVID‑19 curfew and market closures impact informal workers
column7: The Kenyan government’s national curfew and partial lockdown during the COVID‑19 pandemic closed markets and restricted movement, disrupting the livelihoods of daily wage earners, vendors and boda boda operators; no targeted rescue measures were provided.
column13: {"informal_impact": "direct", "impact_channels": ["curfews", "market closures", "transport restrictions"], "affected_informal_groups": ["daily wage workers", "vendors", "boda boda"], "severity": "high", "data_granularity": "episodic"}

column7: To contain the spread of COVID‑19, Kenya imposed a nationwide curfew and restricted movement and market operations, leading to the closure of informal markets and reduced trading hours.
column13: {"informal_impact": "direct", "impact_channels": ["curfews", "market closures"], "affected_informal_groups": ["informal workers"], "policy_type": "public health emergency"}

column6: Social protection programmes for informal workers
column7: Programmes like Haba Haba and Mbao encourage informal workers to save for retirement. However, World Bank analysis notes that social assistance coverage and adequacy remain low, with spending on social safety nets about 0.3% of GDP.
column13: {"informal_impact": "direct", "impact_channels": ["social security", "pensions"], "affected_informal_groups": ["informal workers", "retirees"], "policy_phase": "ongoing"}

column6: IMF lending suspension and informal employment
column7: The IMF lending suspension and subsequent conditionality amplified hardships among informal workers who formed the majority of the workforce.
column13: {"source_type": "shock", "source_id": "shock_2003_imf_freeze", "target_type": "informal_indicator", "target_id": "KE_INF_IND_2000_2010_informal_employment_share", "relation": "amplified", "mechanism_note": "High informal employment share meant most workers lacked social protection; IMF loan suspension and conditionality increased economic hardship, amplifying stress in informal livelihoods.", "confidence": 0.4, "evidence_refs": ["\u3010663989761823768\u2020L20-L54\u3011", "\u3010696902548373840\u2020L82-L120\u3011"]}

column6: Informal employment rise and constitutional protest
column7: Growing precarity in informal employment preceded the constitutional reform protests.
column13: {"source_type": "informal_indicator", "source_id": "KE_INF_IND_2010_2021_informal_employment_share", "target_type": "incident", "target_id": "incident_2009_constitution_protest", "relation": "preceded", "mechanism_note": "The rise in informal employment through the 2010s reflected limited formal job prospects; this growing precarity preceded civic mobilisations for constitutional and socio-economic reforms.", "confidence": 0.3, "evidence_refs": ["\u3010509250893375210\u2020L2477-L2483\u3011", "\u3010437454675774348\u2020L94-L105\u3011"]}

column7: Restrictions during COVID‑19 directly triggered a shock to informal livelihoods.
column13: {"source_type": "policy", "source_id": "policy_2020_covid_curfew", "target_type": "episode", "target_id": "episode_2020_covid_informal", "relation": "triggered", "mechanism_note": "The national curfew and market restrictions introduced in March 2020 directly suppressed economic activity in informal markets, triggering a livelihood shock for daily wage earners and traders.", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence_refs": ["\u3010509250893375210\u2020L1070-L1080\u3011"]}

column6: Social protection reforms respond to low coverage
column7: Policy reforms sought to improve social protection for informal workers in response to evidence of limited coverage.

column6: Informal job dominance and earlier unrest
column7: High informal job share preceded protests during constitutional reform debates.

column6: SME employment share and IMF conditions
column7: Dominance of SMEs and informal employment links back to early 2000s economic reforms.
